Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2009 02:20PM CrystalLocket wrote: I had calcifications for years before my cancer was found.  I had ILC, a very hard to diagnose cancer.  When I was diagnosed I was told it was there for years and was probably mistaken as calcifications.  I tell you this not to scare you, but to give you all of the knowledge I wish I had.  My daughter frequently says that when they start to talk about calcifications to her (as she anticipates) that she's opting for a bilateral mastectomy.  It's totally over the top sounding I know, but I agree with her.  I had nodes affected and am now going through chemo and years of hormonal therapy.  If I knew then what I know now.  Can you ask about your options?  It seems to me that after everything you've been through it might be good to consider getting rid of all of the worry and testing?  Good luck and take care of yourself.
Posts.Title: Nodules & Calcifications Momof6 1osugrl

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2009 04:26PM CrystalLocket wrote: Nurse called and said that the swelling is a SE of taxotere.  My doctor does not do fractionated dosing.  He also only uses Abraxane if the cancer comes back.  I will just stick it out but make sure at my next therapy that the meds are administered slower.
Posts.Title: Anyone else allergic to taxotere? peggyc CrystalLocket

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2009 12:48PM - edited Apr 21, 2009 05:31PM by CrystalLocket My first cycle went fine. My nurse was great and very careful.  The doctor told me he did not expect any further side effects other than losing my hair.  My blood work was okay.  My second cycle was scheduled for 12:30pm and I did not get in until 3:30 pm as they were overbooked.  I did not see 'my' nurse but got another doctor's nurse who was in a rush and set the machine on so fast it was ridiculous.  My hand started to get a freezing feeling and then started to burn. That nurse had walked away as soon as she started me and did not make sure there were no negative reactions.   My chair was in a hidden corner and I did not know where the call button was located so I yelled out for help and another nurse came in and set the timing way down.  The next day I had severe diarrhea and felt like the flu, really tired and out of it.  I then broke out in red spots on my bald scalp. Now I have swollen feet and ankles that I am worried about.  I tend to think it is all due to the way the second cycle was delivered.  The doctor's office was called yesterday and all they said was to put your feet up.  I have not heard from the nurse on call yet.  I am hoping it is not kidney damage or something permanent.
Posts.Title: Anyone else allergic to taxotere? peggyc CrystalLocket

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2009 07:42PM - edited Feb 17, 2009 08:55PM by CrystalLocket Just wanted to recap, I had my bilat mast on 1/21/09 with 11 nodes taken out on the right, I had a skin reaction to the antibiotic (which is much better today) and I have all drains out as of yesterday.  Today I actually went to the store by myself!

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2009 04:37PM CrystalLocket wrote: I just got back from the doctor to talk about the pathology.  What a relief.  We knew it was in the nodes, but we didn't know how much.  It is in 1 node and is 0.3 cm in that node.  The tumor itself was 1 cm.  I have yet to meet with the oncologist, but the doctor mentioned possibly skipping the chemo.  Do you all think that's possible?
Posts.Title: January Mastectomy crusader1 bettelou68

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2009 11:07AM CrystalLocket wrote: I had many calcifications in my breasts for years, and my armpit was just sore in general (to the touch as well as an achy constant feeling that got progressively worse).  I didn't really feel a llump, but I've read that doctors can feel a lump (as the gland is swollen) if cancer is present so it's best to demand further attention to it if the doctor brushes it off.  I went to the doctor for my routine mammogram and mentioned the pain.  They found my cancer on that mammogram.  They could tell from the mammogram that it was cancer, they actually told me before I had the biopsy.  Then I had the biopsy to confirm (for insurance reasons) and then a double mastectomy (which is not nearly as painful as it sounds) last week.  I hope you find that it's nothing to be concerned about. (hugs)
Posts.Title: armpit pain - a little swollen gland? bopsie MinusTwo

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2009 10:45AM - edited Jan 30, 2009 10:45AM by CrystalLocket I had pain in my armpit before my diagnosis.  My breast cancer had spread to one lymph node.  I had no lump in my breast as I had invasive lobular carcinoma.  Good luck and keep us updated.
Posts.Title: armpit pain - a little swollen gland? bopsie MinusTwo

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2012 07:28AM CrystalLocket wrote: I was told I had the bones of a 25 year old, but after chemo I was into osteopenia.  I also noticed that the skin on my face lost 'life' for loss of a better word. I now have slight hollows under my eyes where I didn't before.  The skin on my legs used to be taut but now is crinkley on the surface.  I am moisturizing and using a humidifier.  Also, I have a friend who is a smoker and she looks younger than her years, I asked what her secret was and she said she takes daily pre-natal vitimans...haha...  So off I went to the health food store and sure enough I do notice an improvement after a few days on them and watching what I eat & drink.  Drinking alcohol really shows & drys my skin so I only have that on special occasions.  I now be sure to drink water throughout the day to hydrate my body.
Posts.Title: Dry skin & wrinkles after chemo? jenlee Dthayer
Dry skin & wrinkles after chemo? jenlee Dthayer

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2010 08:13PM CrystalLocket wrote: I went for therapy for lymph swelling in my arm.  The compression machine helped the most and then I wore a sleeve.  I don't have to wear it all the time, but there is a noticable size difference in my arms always.   I have heard of surgeries where they take nodes from another place in the body to implant but then that might cause swelling in those sites maybe.  I love Celtic Spirit's comebacks to inquiring minds!  Very Funny.

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2009 04:34PM - edited Jan 26, 2009 04:35PM by CrystalLocket It turns out that there was a small pinhole in the tube.  I have no idea how that happened and they said they've never seen it before (of course it happens to me, lol).  Anyway, they said everything else looks fine and they cut the tube shorter (too short if you ask me) and reattached the "granade".  Thanks for everyone's insight!
